TestDescription.name: Insecure response with wildcard '*' in Access-Control-Allow-Origin
TestDescription.Description: Cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) is a mechanism that allows restricted resources (e.g. fonts) on a web page to be requested from another domain outside the domain from which the resource originated. The Access-Control-Allow-Origin header indicates whether a resource can be shared based by returning the value of the Origin request header, "[bold][dark]*[/dark][/bold]", or "null" in the response. [break][break] If a website responds with Access-Control-Allow-Origin: [bold][dark]*[/dark][/bold] the requested resource allows sharing with every origin. Therefore, any website can make XHR (XMLHTTPRequest) requests to your site and access the responses. It's not recommended to use the Access-Control-Allow-Origin: [bold][dark]*[/dark][/bold] header.
TestDescription.Impact: Any website can make XHR requests to your site and access the responses.
TestDescription.Recommendation: Is recommended not to use Access-Control-Allow-Origin: [bold][dark]*[/dark][/bold]. Instead the Access-Control-Allow-Origin header should contain the list of origins that can make COR requests.
